thread.section_title: Stock Market & Finance News - Wall Street Journal
thread.title: Oil Tumbles as Major Producers Discuss Lifting Output

author: Neanda Salvaterra
title: Oil Tumbles as Major Producers Discuss Lifting Output

organizations.name: major producers discuss lifting output oil

text:
3 COMMENTS Oil prices tumbled Friday as major oil producers including Saudi Arabia and Russia signaled a willingness to pump more crude into the market.
Brent crude, the global oil benchmark, fell 2.2% to $77.08 a barrel on London’s ICE Futures exchange. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate futures were trading down 1.9% at $69.40 a barrel.
Saudi Arabian oil minister Khalid al-Falih on Friday said he would enter into discussions in June with other members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and external producers such as Russia to relax the output caps, Bloomberg reported.
The move comes in response to crude prices that have reached an almost three-year high and are beginning to hit consumers in the pocket.
Mr. Falih, the de facto head of OPEC, said consumer anxiety “is a concern to us,” according to Bloomberg.
“You can interpret this in a bullish sense and a bearish sense,” said Bjarne Schieldrop, the chief commodities analyst at SEB Markets. “Putting some oil back into the market will prevent oil prices from going to $100 in the second half of 2018, which is good. But it also means that come 2019 there is no more buffer left and it is going to be needed.”
OPEC and a handful of external producers such as Russia have been involved in an effort since 2016 to remove almost 2% of the global crude supply in a bid to prop up crude’s value.
Analysts are projecting that the oil market will move into a deficit in the second part of this year and 2019 of 0.5 million barrels and later 0.3 million barrels a day as demand outstrips supply.
An employee stands at a site inside the Zubair oil and gas field, north of the southern Iraqi province of Basra. Photo: haidar mohammed ali/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images Experts warn that major geopolitical events could throw a wrench into the market.
U.S. President Donald Trump canceled a meeting to negotiate with North Korea over its nuclear program, and analysts warn that a ratcheting up of tensions between Washington and Pyongyang could weigh on oil consumption.
“Oil demand could suffer if the North Korean conflict were to flare up again,” said analysts for Commerzbank in a recent note. “After all, three of the world’s five largest oil import countries are to be found in the region: China, Japan and South Korea.”
Turmoil in the Middle East and the reimposition of U.S. trade sanctions against major oil producer Iran have also supported crude.
Still, the Trump administration’s plan to tighten the economic thumbscrews on Tehran is likely to remove an estimated 0.5 million barrels a day from the market and experts fear the move may further worsen the deficit.
Later on Friday investors will be looking ahead to data on U.S. shale oil production.
Oil services firm Baker Hughes Inc. is set to release its weekly data on the number of rigs drilling for oil in the U.S., a bellwether for activity in the sector.
Nymex reformulated gasoline blendstock—the benchmark gasoline contract—fell 1.98% to $2.18 a gallon. ICE gas oil changed hands at $682.50 a metric ton, down $16.75 from the previous settlement.
Write to Neanda Salvaterra at neanda.salvaterra@wsj.com
